channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: Inside the NSA's Secret Tool for Mapping Your Social Network
item.description: Edward Snowden revealed the agency's phone-record tracking program. But thanks to 'precomputed contact chaining,' that database was much more powerful than anyone knew.

item.title: Coronavirus in the U.S.: Latest Map and Case Count
item.description: A detailed county map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with tables of the number of cases by county.

item.title: No Masks Allowed: Stores Turn Customers Away in US Culture War
item.description: Shops around the US make headlines for denying entry to those wearing masks as protesters argue against preventative measures in the name of freedom

item.title: Researchers Squeeze 44.2 Tbps Through Existing Fiber Optic Cables
item.description: Researchers in Australia used a device called a microcomb to break the record for the fastest internet connection.

item.title: Yes, the Patriot Act Amendment to Track Us Online Is Real
item.description: Looks like more bad news with the renewal of the Patriot Act/USA Freedom Act — and its terrible provision to allow government collection of Americans' internet browsing and search histories without a warrant.

item.title: China Drops Word 'Peaceful' in Latest Push for Taiwan 'Reunification'
item.description: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang left out the word 'peaceful' on Friday in referring to Beijing's desire to 'reunify' with Chinese-claimed Taiwan, an apparent policy shift that comes as ties with Taipei continue on a downward spiral.

item.title: It Hit 80 Degrees in the Arctic This Week
item.description: This story will provide important context for the headline, and I encourage you to read it—but really, the headline tells you what you need to know: It was 80 degrees Fahrenheit above the Arctic Circle this week.

item.title: The U.S. Brags About Health Aid to Africa While Bombing Some of Its Most Vulnerable Nations
item.description: Libya and Somalia, where U.S. forces have spent hundreds of millions on airstrikes, have fared especially poorly when it comes to direct U.S. health assistance.

item.title: Just Turning Your Phone on Qualifies as Searching It, Court Rules
item.description: Location data requires a warrant since 2018; lock screen may now, too.

item.title: What Every Pharmaceutical Commercial Is REALLY Saying
item.description: Consume. www.trustourbrand.com

item.title: Congress Has No Idea How Much Web Browsing Data the FBI Collects
item.description: The Patriot Act is about to be reauthorized, but we still don't know basic facts about how our web browsing habits are being collected.

item.title: Nearly Half of Twitter Accounts Pushing to Reopen America May Be Bots
item.description: Kathleen M. Carley and her team at Carnegie Mellon University's Center for Informed Democracy & Social Cybersecurity have been tracking bots and influence campaigns for a long time. Across US and foreign elections, natural disasters, and other politicized events, the level of bot involvement is norm…

item.title: California: 1,200 Pastors Say They Will Defy State Order and Resume Services
item.description: State allowing some businesses to reopen, but churches still banned. As many as 3,000 churches could hold services on 31 May

item.title: The CIA's Murderous Practices, Disinformation Campaigns, and Interference in Other Countries Still Shape the World Order and U.S. Politics
item.description: No understanding of international or domestic politics is possible without a factual grasp of the CIA's purpose.

item.title: 'We've Been Muzzled': CDC Sources Say White House Putting Politics Ahead of Science
item.description: In the early weeks of the US coronavirus outbreak, staff members in the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had tracked a growing number of transmissions in Europe and elsewhere, and proposed a global advisory that would alert flyers to the dangers of air travel.

item.title: Acting U.S. Spy Chief Questioned Over Warrantless Capture of Americans' Web Browsing History
item.description: U.S. Senator Ron Wyden, the sponsor of a recent amendment to stop the FBI from capturing Americans' search and web browsing histories without a warrant, is now asking the nation's top spy (acting) to disclose whether his office has accurately reported on such activities, which the law seemingly requ…

item.title: EasyJet Admits Data of Nine Million Hacked
item.description: The attack was 'sophisticated' the airline said, adding that some credit card details had been accessed.

item.title: Maryland Reopens—and Quickly Sees Its Largest COVID-19 Spike
item.description: Health officials worry reopening amid continued spread could spark second wave.

item.title: Ousted Scientist Says She Was Asked to Manipulate Florida COVID-19 Data
item.description: Jones said she was ordered 'to manually change data' to support reopening.

item.title: 'People Are Sick All Around Me': Inside the Coronavirus Catastrophe in California Prisons
item.description: Prisoners and advocates told the Guardian that some infected inmates are in isolation without medical care or adequate food, cut off from family and attorneys

item.title: Trump Announces Executive Order 'Suspending' Regulations Impeding the Economy
item.description: President hands his Cabinet secretaries broad say to nix more regulations

item.title: He Opposed Public Lands and Wildlife Protections. Trump Gave Him a Top Environment Job
item.description: Under the leadership of William Perry Pendley, the Bureau of Land Management is failing to fulfill its most basic duties of safeguarding America's public lands, his critics say

item.title: Let's Rebuild the Broken Meat Industry—Without Animals
item.description: Covid-19 has laid bare many flaws of industrialized animal agriculture. Plant- and cell-based alternatives offer a more resilient solution.

item.title: Climate Change Is Turning Antarctica's Snow Green
item.description: As the planet warms, parts of the planet are going green—and not in the environmentally friendly way. Snow in coastal Antarctica is literally turning the color green.

item.title: 'Not a Mask in Sight': Thousands Flock to Yellowstone as Park Reopens
item.description: With support of the Trump administration, Yellowstone and Grand Teton national parks have partially reopened after Covid-19 closures

item.title: FBI Power to Warrantlessly Seize Your Web Browsing History May Hinge on a Single Democrat
item.description: Republicans and Democrats engrossed in a fight over the future of privacy in America say the public support of a specific influential Democrat is likely critical to secure a vote next week on an amendment that would prohibit FBI agents from demanding Americans' web browsing data without a warrant.

item.title: Covid-19's Toll on Prison Labor Doesn't Just Hurt Inmates
item.description: Work stoppages impact the incarcerated workforce as well. The financial losses extend beyond the walls.

item.title: America Just Made a Huge Investment in Next-Gen Nuclear Power
item.description: That means tinier, better reactors in the near future.

item.title: Your Equifax Settlement $125 Isn't Coming, but Banks Get Their $5.5M
item.description: Sure, you might only get a few cents at this point, but where is it?

item.title: The Trump Administration Gave a Drug-Making Contract Worth Up to $812 Million to a Small Virginia Firm Founded Less Than 6 Months Ago
item.description: The Trump administration is plowing hundreds of millions into boosting US medicine manufacturing, fearing an overreliance on foreign companies.

item.title: Ukraine Catches Hacker Who Tried to Sell 773 Million Stolen Email Addresses
item.description: Ukrainian officials detained the hacker, known as Sanix, who tried to sell a database with 773 million email addresses and 21 million unique passwords.

item.title: Honest Political Ads - Gil Fulbright for Senate
item.description: Join the movement to end political corruption: www.represent.us What would an honest politician actually sound like? America's biggest problems are going uns...

item.title: Hollow Point Bullets Recalled That Don't Explode in Targets
item.description: Steel Hawk Inc. is offering a full refund to customers who bought the non-flesh-shredding bullets.

item.title: First Female Dictator Hailed as Step Forward for Women
item.description: Amivi Gama's violent rise to power in East Timor has proved that women are just as capable as men when it comes to brutality and oppression.

item.title: Memorial Honors Victims of Imminent Dam Disaster
item.description: Officials in California dedicated the Folsom Dam Memorial, which will honor the nearby residents that will die when the faulty dam fails.

item.title: It's Called Artificial Intelligence — But What Is Intelligence?
item.description: We've built machines that are capable of incredible feats, yet still they have nothing on a baby.

item.title: Is the Brain a Useful Model for Artificial Intelligence?
item.description: Thinking machines think just like us—but only up to a point.

item.title: Are AI-Powered Killer Robots Inevitable?
item.description: Military scholars warn of a 'battlefield singularity,' a point at which humans can no longer keep up with the pace of conflict.

item.title: 'First Ever' Near Real-Time Analysis of Global Carbon Emissions Reveals Coronavirus Impacts
item.description: Lockdowns around the world are having a measurable effect on global greenhouse gas emissions. A new study out Tuesday found that daily emissions dropped by 17 percent in April 2020 compared to last year's average levels. This is a sizable dip, but the findings offer a sobering reality check: Individ…

item.title: It's Time to Dismantle Factory Farms and Get Used to Eating Less Meat
item.description: We should envision a more resilient and sustainable food system, one that doesn't commodify sentient life

item.title: Carbon Dioxide Emissions Have Dropped 17 Percent During the Pandemic
item.description: Some regions, like the US and the UK, have seen their outputs fall by a third, due in large part to people driving less.

item.title: As Machines Get Smarter, How Will We Relate to Them?
item.description: Millennia of evolution have left us ill prepared to crack open the black box of AI and peer inside.

item.title: Alarm and Confusion at Fox News as Trump Says He Takes Hydroxychloroquine
item.description: Fox News viewers were warned not to take medical advice from the president, following Donald Trump's announcement that he takes the drug hydroxychloroquine.

item.title: Watch a Boston Dynamics Robot Herd Sheep in New Zealand
item.description: New Zealand-based robotics company Rocos shared a video of Boston Dynamics' Spot herding sheep across grassy pastures.

item.title: The Arctic Is Unraveling as a Massive Heat Wave Grips the Region
item.description: It wouldn't be spring in the climate change era without a massive heat wave in the Arctic.

item.title: US Lockdown Protests May Have Spread Virus Widely, Cellphone Data Suggests
item.description: Devices associated with protesters travelled up to hundreds of miles after rallies where few precautions were taken

item.title: CDC Sued Over 'Pattern' of Mishandling Freedom of Information Requests During Pandemic
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is facing a lawsuit over its alleged mishandling of records requests under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Plaintiffs accuse the agency of 'systematically obstruct[ing]' attempts by the public to acquire details about the government's handl…

item.title: China's Air Pollution Is Now Worse Than Pre-Coronavirus Levels
item.description: Last month, China finally ended its coronavirus lockdown. While air quality improved dramatically during The Quiet Time, new data shows it was short-lived. What's more, air pollution is coming back at higher levels than during the same period last year.

item.title: Cell-Tower Attacks by Idiots Who Claim 5G Spreads COVID-19 Reportedly Hit US
item.description: US warns carriers to boost security, citing reports of attacks in several states.

item.title: Federal Government Buys Riot Gear, Increases Security Funding, Citing Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The orders are for disposable cuffs, gas masks, ballistic helmets, riot gloves, and equipment for federal police assigned to Veterans Affairs facilities.

item.title: 'Stealth Bailout' Shovels Millions of Dollars to Oil Companies
item.description: As it headed toward bankruptcy, Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc. took advantage of a little-noticed provision in the stimulus bill Congress passed in March to get a $9.7 million tax refund. Then, it asked a bankruptcy judge to authorize the same amount as bonuses to nine executives.

item.title: U.S. Government Proposed Manipulating CDC Guidelines to Avoid Mask Shortages: Whistleblower
item.description: The U.S. government proposed manipulating information about whether N95 masks worked to fight the spread of coronavirus in the general public, according to Dr. Richard Bright, a whistleblower who testified publicly for the first time on Thursday. The deception was an effort to avoid shortages and ke…

item.title: Whistleblower: Wall Street Has Engaged in Widespread Manipulation of Mortgage Funds
item.description: Securities that contain loans for properties like hotels and office buildings have inflated profits, the whistleblower claims. As the pandemic hammers the economy, that could increase the chances of another mortgage collapse.

item.title: Senate Votes to Reauthorize FBI Surveillance Powers, With a Few Worthwhile Tweaks
item.description: In an 80-16 vote on Thursday, the U.S. Senate passed a bill to restore controversial surveillance tools used by the FBI in terrorism and espionage investigations. But the bill has at least one more hurdle to jump thanks to a series of changes implemented yesterday.

item.title: Struggling Oil Companies Are Taking Advantage of US Coronavirus Aid
item.description: Recent review finds at least $113m in taxpayer-backed loans meant for small businesses have gone to fossil fuel industry

item.title: Senate Passes Spying Bill Without Search and Browsing History Protections
item.description: An amendment protecting search and browsing histories failed in a 59-37 vote.

item.title: In a First, Renewable Energy Is Poised to Eclipse Coal in U.S.
item.description: The coronavirus has pushed the coal industry to once-unthinkable lows, and the consequences for climate change are big.

item.title: Police Shot and Killed a 26-Year-Old EMT in Her Apartment While Looking for Someone Else Entirely
item.description: Breonna Taylor had no criminal record, and police found no drugs in her home.

item.title: FBI Accuses China of Attempting to Steal US COVID-19 Research
item.description: The FBI warns that China-backed hackers are attempting to steal COVID-19 research from organizations in the US.

item.title: Here's Who Just Voted to Let the FBI Seize Your Online Search History Without a Warrant
item.description: A bipartisan amendment that would have prohibited law enforcement agencies, such as the FBI, from obtaining the web browsing and internet search histories of Americans without a warrant failed to pass in the U.S. Senate on Wednesday by a single vote.

item.title: The New Alzheimer's–Air Pollution Link
item.description: Toxic airborne particles can travel from lungs and nose to the brain, and exposure is linked to memory loss

item.title: U.S. Warns That Chinese Hackers Are Targeting Virus Research
item.description: Hackers working for the Chinese government are trying to steal valuable research on coronavirus vaccines and treatments from U.S. health care, pharmaceutical and research organizations, the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security warned Wednesday.

item.title: Your Boss Is Watching You: Work-From-Home Boom Leads to More Surveillance
item.description: With more people now working from home, employers are increasingly relying on tracking software to monitor what employees do when they're on the clock.

item.title: Big Oil's Climate Plans Don't Come Close to Meeting the Paris Agreement
item.description: Climate action plans are all the rage for polluting companies. Last month, Shell pledged to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. It's just the latest example: Other oil giants have recently made similar pledges as well. These pronouncements use pseudo-inspirational marketing speak, promising to …

item.title: COVID-19 Resurges in Reopened Countries; Wuhan Sees First Cluster in a Month
item.description: China ordered all Wuhan residents get tested for COVID-19—that's ~11 million people.

item.title: Federal Whistleblower Says Boss Pushed Him to Buy Drugs That Hadn't Been Tested in Humans
item.description: Rick Bright's complaint points to the influence of industry over the Trump administration's coronavirus response.

item.title: That Fresh Sea Breeze You Breathe May Be Laced With Microplastic
item.description: Researchers have discovered that the ocean is burping tiny plastic particles, which then blow onto land—and potentially into your lungs.

item.title: Online Voting Has Worked So Far. That Doesn't Mean It's Safe
item.description: Proponents of mobile and internet voting point to its uneventful track record. That's not good enough.

item.title: Large Chunks of a Chinese Rocket Missed New York City by About 15 Minutes
item.description: China's Long March 5B rocket launched without a second stage.

item.title: How Much Is a Human Life Actually Worth?
item.description: As the US economy reopens amid a deadly pandemic, a dire question looms. Let's weigh the risks—and do the math.

item.title: The Bailout Is Working — for the Rich
item.description: The economy is in free fall but Wall Street is thriving, and stocks of big private equity firms are soaring dramatically higher. That tells you who investors think is the real beneficiary of the federal government's massive rescue efforts.

item.title: The Pandemic Is Bringing Back Single-Use Plastics in a Huge Way
item.description: States are rolling back their plastic bag bans and restaurants are turning to single-use utensils to reopen in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: At Least $72 Million in Coronavirus Bailout Loans Went to Big Oil and Gas Companies
item.description: At least 16 drillers, fuel transporters, oil technology firms and service providers tapped the Small Business Association's Paycheck Protection Program.

item.title: With a Distracted Public, the Pentagon Tries to Get Away With Killing Innocent Civilians
item.description: The Pentagon's annual report to Congress covering civilian casualties appears to be yet another case of woefully underreporting innocent deaths.

item.title: US Marshals Says Prisoners' Personal Information Taken in Data Breach
item.description: Current and former prisoners were notified of the breach on May 1.

item.title: U.S. Unemployment Just Hit Its Highest Level Since the Great Depression
item.description: The American job market is in full-on meltdown.

item.title: For Cops Who Kill, Special Supreme Court Protection
item.description: The U.S. high court's continual refinement of an obscure doctrine called qualified immunity has made it harder to hold police liable for excessive force.

item.title: An Oil Spill and the Coronavirus Are Creating a Crisis in Ecuador's Amazon
item.description: Imagine being told to shelter at home due to a global pandemic, only to have your home, drinking water, and food stores destroyed. It would be a nightmare, but that is exactly what happened for indigenous people in the Ecuadorian Amazon after a massive oil spill polluted two major rivers.

item.title: CDC Guide to Reopening Was Trashed by the Trump Admin. It Just Leaked
item.description: Trump admin allegedly told CDC its reopening guide would 'never see the light of day.'

item.title: We Are Tenants on Our Own Devices
item.description: It's time to assert our sovereignty over our own stuff.

item.title: Whistleblower Details How HHS Officials Refused to Secure N95 Masks as Pandemic Loomed
item.description: The report from Richard Bright reveals a new villain in the tragic saga of the administration's mismanagement of the coronavirus crisis: Robert Kadlec.

item.title: Farmers Are Destroying Mountains of Food. Here's What to Do About It
item.description: The Covid-19 pandemic has revealed the cracks in a corporate-focused system supported by polices that favor profits at any cost

item.title: Prisons Will Worsen Coronavirus Crisis in Rural America
item.description: The prison economy has been a lifeline for rural communities for decades, but that lifeline has transformed into a vector for coronavirus.

item.title: We've Known How to Make Healthier Buildings for Decades
item.description: During the pandemic, people are now demanding them.

item.title: Nearly 20,000 Teens in Georgia Have Received Their Driver's Licenses Without a Road Test
item.description: Georgia isn't the only state that is waiving road tests. Wisconsin announced this week that it will start doing the same for 16- and 17-year-olds, starting Monday.

item.title: Here Are the Companies Getting Rich From the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Scott Disick, of 'Keeping Up With the Kardashians' fame, pushed out a line of T-shirts and hoodies emblazoned with the timely message 'Wash Your Hands.'

item.title: Mass Incarceration Poses a Uniquely American Risk in the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The virus has exposed just how deadly prisons and jails are for incarcerated people, and for society at large.

item.title: U.S. Companies Cut Thousands of Workers While Continuing to Reward Shareholders During Pandemic
item.description: As the pandemic squeezes big companies, executives are making decisions about who will bear the brunt of the sacrifices, and in at least some cases, workers have been the first to lose, even as shareholders continue to collect.

item.title: Speaker Pelosi Supports Push for Taxpayer Bailout of Corporate Lobbyists
item.description: Trade groups have stepped up a campaign for $25 billion and PPP eligibility in the next phase of coronavirus relief.

item.title: America's Renewable Energy Sources Have Produced More Electricity Than Coal Every Day for 40 Days Straight
item.description: The transition away from coal for electricity generation in the U.S. accelerated in 2020 due to lower gas prices, warmer weather and the economic conditions resulting from COVID-19, analysis found.

item.title: An AI Can Simulate an Economy Millions of Times to Create Fairer Tax Policy
item.description: Deep reinforcement learning has trained AIs to beat humans at complex games like Go and StarCraft. Could it also do a better job at running the economy?

item.title: U.K. Reports Highest Coronavirus Death Toll in Europe
item.description: It surpassed Italy.

item.title: Jared Kushner's Shadow Coronavirus Task Force Used a Spreadsheet Called 'VIP Update' to Procure PPE From Inexperienced Trump Allies Over Legitimate Vendors
item.description: In theory, the group was supposed to find the most promising leads on protective gear and funnel them to FEMA. Instead, it prioritized Trump allies.

item.title: US Projects 200,000 New COVID-19 Cases per Day, 3,000 Daily Deaths by June
item.description: Leaked gov't document predicts rise in deaths as Trump aims to 'open up America.'

item.title: Three Russian Doctors Fall From Hospital Windows, Raising Questions Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Three frontline health care workers have mysteriously fallen out of hospital windows in Russia over the past two weeks, heightening public attention to the working conditions for doctors and medical professionals amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: The World Came Together for a Virtual Vaccine Summit. The U.S. Was Conspicuously Absent.
item.description: International donors are on track to raise $8.2 billion to mass-produce drugs, vaccines and testing kits. The Trump administration says the U.S. remains the world's largest health and humanitarian donor.

item.title: How Many Jobs Do Robots Really Replace?
item.description: MIT economist Daron Acemoglu's new research puts a number on the job costs of automation.

item.title: Hostile States Trying to Steal Coronavirus Research, Says UK Agency
item.description: Experts say Russia, Iran and China likely to be behind cyber-attacks on universities

item.title: US Store Guard Killed After Mask Row With Customer
item.description: A Michigan store guard is shot in the back of the head after confronting a customer who had no mask.

item.title: China Thinks Backlash to Its Coronavirus Response Could Lead to All-Out War With the U.S.
item.description: A State Security report warned that anti-China sentiment, led by the U.S., has not been this high since the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.

item.title: Which States Are Reopening, Which Remain on Lockdown, and Why
item.description: There's not a national plan to restart US businesses. That's led to inconsistencies among governors' orders, and some confusion among residents.

item.title: Medical Expert: Federal Jail Intentionally Destroying Medical Records and Hiding Extent of Coronavirus Behind Bars
item.description: 'Several current practices in MDC actually promote a more rapid spread of COVID-19 inside the facility.'

item.title: Donald Trump's Four-Step Plan to Reopen the US Economy – and Why It Will Be Lethal
item.description: The president and his allies are hiding the facts and pretending 'freedom' conquers all. As a result, more Americans will die

item.title: White House Blocks Fauci From Testifying to Congress on Coronavirus Response
item.description: Top U.S. health official Anthony Fauci will not testify next week to a congressional committee examining the Trump administration's response to the coronavirus pandemic, the White House said on Friday, calling it 'counterproductive' to have individuals involved in the response testify.

item.title: The World Is Still Producing More Oil Than It Needs. Why?
item.description: Today, petroleum producers around the world will start shutting down wells after the Covid-19 pandemic caused demand to plummet. What took them so long?

item.title: Judge Orders FCC to Hand Over IP Addresses Linked to Fake Net Neutrality Comments
item.description: A Manhattan federal judge has ruled the Federal Communications Commission must provide two reporters access to server logs that may provide new insight into the allegations of fraud stemming from agency's 2017 net neutrality rollback.

item.title: Congress Is Investigating Cruise Ship Company Carnival Over COVID-19 Outbreaks
item.description: Carnival is accused of failing to take action when it knew the risks of the novel coronavirus.

item.title: China Warns Australia It Could Face Boycotts Over Call for an Independent Inquiry Into Coronavirus
item.description: China has accused Australia of parroting the United States in its call for an inquiry independent of the WHO to determine the origins of COVID-19.

item.title: Jobs Collapse Is Deeper Than the Government Says
item.description: Economists' workforce surveys are more current than the government's. And more terrifying.

item.title: People With Guns (And No Masks) Swarmed the Michigan State Capitol to Protest the Coronavirus Lockdown
item.description: Some state legislators, anticipating the possibility of violence, had even come to work that day wearing bulletproof vests.

item.title: 'Microplastic Hot Spots' Are Tainting Deep-Sea Ecosystems
item.description: Scientists found 2 million microplastic particles in a square meter of sediment, as currents drag debris into seafloor versions of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

item.title: Pence Threatened to Punish the Reporter Who Proved His Office Ignored the Rule That He Needed a Mask to Visit the Mayo Clinic
item.description: Steve Herman undermined Pence's wife's claim that the vice president didn't know he was supposed to wear a mask during the much-criticized visit.

item.title: It Could Take Decades for the Ocean Floor to Recover From Deep Sea Mining
item.description: A new study has found that the impacts of deep sea mining are still felt a quarter of a century later.

item.title: Stocks Are Recovering While the Economy Collapses. That Makes More Sense Than You'd Think.
item.description: While the economy is contracting, the market is soaring. If you look closely at what's up and down, it actually makes sense--for now.

item.title: Google Play Has Been Spreading Advanced Android Malware for Years
item.description: Advanced hacker group seeded market with at least 8 apps likely since 2016.

item.title: The Pandemic Is Accelerating Coal's Demise
item.description: Electricity in Europe, India, China, and parts of the U.S. is less and less reliant on coal.

item.title: Inside the Race to Build the Best Quantum Computer on Earth
item.description: Google's most advanced computer isn't at the company's headquarters in Mountain View, California, nor anywhere in the febrile sprawl of Silicon Valley. It's a few hours' drive south in Santa Barbara, in a flat, soulless office park inhabited mostly by technology firms you've never heard of. An open-…
